I like

POST /Orders/Cancelled?url=3D/Orders/333

It sort of feels like pla=
cing the order in the pile of canceled
orders.  Viewing the cancelled order=
s is as simple as

GET /Orders/Cancelled

and re-opening the order is

POST=
 /Orders/Open?url=3D/Orders/333

It's not the only way but it works for me.=


Darrel

On Fri, May 8, 2009 at 6:09 PM, Bill Burke <bburke@...> wr=
ote:
>
>
> Let's say I have an Order resource in a ecommerce Order Entry sy=
stem.
> How would I implement my service so that I can cancel an order rath=
er
> than delete it? One is to have the cancel state as part of the order.
=
> THen I can just put a new representation with the cancelled state set to
=
> true:
>
> PUT /orders/333
> content-type: application/xml
>
> <order id=
=3D"333">
> <cancelled>false</cancelled>
> ...
> </order>
>
> Seems kinda h=
eavy to me.
>
> Would it still be restful to define a "cancelled" URI that =
you could put
> or post to to change the state?
>
> /orders/333/cancelled
>=

> or
>
> /orders/333?cancel=3Dtrue
>
> You don't even need to send data to=
 change the state in this scenario.
> But the problem with this from a pure=
 RESTful standpoint is, isn't this
> a mini-RPC? My thought at first is YES=
 IT IS....
>
> .... But, consider if you have cancelling as part of a HATEO=
AS
>
> <order id=3D"333">
> <atom:link rel=3D"CANCEL" href=3D"http://exampl=
e.com/orders/333/cancelled"/>
> ...
> </order>
>
> Now, I have a CANCEL lin=
k that if I follow changes the state of my
> resource. Doesn't seem so RPCi=
sh now that I've embedded it as a link.
> Maybe the answer is /orders/333/c=
ancelled isn't very RESTful by itself,
> but when combined with HATEOAS it =
is?
